captions.text: Good afternoon everyone..
Im really happy to be here,
I might have a peculiar proffesion.
It's true what Karina said,
that I am a street jazz musician.
You could even say I'm a school drop out,
My last education was highschool.
After highschool, I studied graphic design.
Which until now, I have never used.
And why? because I wanted to study music, but there wasn't any music schools.
At that time, there wasn't any good music schools in Indonesia.
that can provide and accomodate what i wanted.

So finally i just decided to try, 
and determined to live a life of music.
Without a proper basic theory.

And tried to explore music 
through autodidact methods.
Although at the end, i had the chance to properly study music theory.
.. but still, you can say that I
don't use theories at all. Because I have a totally different way with everything.
And.. The point is, that I am here to convince that..
If we have a strong enough of a passion, in any field that we are in,

We don't have to have excessive education, 
we don't need anything too grandiose.
It doesn't mean that it's not important.

But if we work hard.
We can achieve our dreams.
Thats one.
And also I'd like to share about how
.. we can make a breakthrough.
For example, the instrument I use is the bass.
Most people recognise the bass as in instrument that is played
.. in the background, or as rhythm.
But right now, I'm playing alone, as you can see.
No drums, no keyboard, no singer.
We'll try to play something.
(Audience applause and cheer)

And one other thing, 
When we play jazz,
Almost everything happens spontaneously.

And it is indeed performing arts,
so it must be like that.

Catch the moment, so hopefully we 
we can together catch the momment.
I need energy from all of you.
(Audience applause and cheer)
Oh yeah, one more thing. I'd like to dedicate this first song

to Arief's sister,
her name is Sari.
It's her birthday today. and he said that he really loves his sister Sari.
(audience sympathize)

Aaahhh..
So this is it! Enjoy.
(Audience applause)
Thank you.
Yes. That was a song from Michael Jackson.

And like I said earlier,
what happens on stage, it happens

at that moment and I couldn't possibly
repeat the same thing.

And it did happen spontaneously.
So bravo to all of you!

.. That has transfered your energy to me.
Thank you.
Hmm.. There are some other things I'd like to say.

Ah.. For example,
maybe like I said,
The bass has always had a tendency to be an instrument in the background.
But, I try to challenge that assumption, that even a bass player, can be a frontman.
And, like I have gone through until now.
I have had a music career for 10 years, since 2000.
Starting from playing in certain clubs.

From cafe to cafe, with a fee thats
quite pathetic..
Some of them just gave mineral water.
Thank God, I can now pay for myself.

And once again, like I said, 
I am a street jazz musician. a drop out.

Here in Indonesia
A lot of people have the assumption

That to play music you need to formally study.
That to play music,
You have to start from classical music. Or have to go to "this" school

or "that" school.
Actually I will challenge that again.
That it isn't true!
Why? Music schools may have monetary motivations.
They need students to study there.

So that, they get paid.
It's simple.

But also, again, 
It doesn't mean that it's not important.

But looking back,
Maybe a lot of people does not have the ability
To go to a music school which is expensive.

So, Once again, I'd like to say
That the talents given by God
.. Is enough actually.
(Audience applause)
Like earlier, I am bold enough to explore something new.
Right now, I also have a group.

Which I call 
Barry Likhumahuwa project.
And..
I'm quite grateful that this group is quite unique.
Because, once again, a bass player can be the frontman.

And can lead a band.
That's something very rare.

But, I challenged it. And I'm sure,
All of you, in any field,
In which your passion is there,
Can do the same thing.
Through, being the person,
That creates change. That's all.
So..
Maybe there are some people in the same industry as I.
I'd like to say a few things.

That the best way, is that if we play music we don't think about RBT. 
(Ring Back Tone)
Or sales.
Or creating songs..
That are easy for people to sing.
For instance, making a song with abbreviations, right?
(Audience Laugh)
T E D X.. Ooo no, not that..
(Audience laugh)
But more importantly,

is how we communicate
a message through the music that we created.

Music in Indonesia,
is still regarded as an entertainment industry.
While abroad, people have used music to achieve a mission.
Like for example, Irvan

Using his "Rock the Peace" Concert, 
He can unite people.
People from different religions to play in 1 stage.

To create peace. 
That is what the world needs now.
And that can be accomplished through music.

Because once again,
Music is a universal language.
A simple exmaple, when i went to Vienna, Austria,
We suceeded in presenting music with very unique collaborations.
Where I played bass, Dwiki Dharmawan on the piano.
And then there Ade Rudiana playing a sundanese drum.
We joined with an Ut player from Arab.
He lives in Dubai, his name is Kamal Musalam.
And a saxophone player from America, his name was Andy Suzuki.
And we suceeded in creating such beautiful music.

And we played some,
We brought Balinese Ceng-ceng there.

And the result was that we were the only performer 
that got a standing ovation.
.. from almost all the audience there.
(Audience Applause)
The point is..

When we suceed in collaborating and synergizing something,
With the same passion

We can make something new, 
and we can communicate a message through music.
That's it..
And that's also what I do.
I've launched 1 album, with the title of "Good Spell"
Not that I want to show off or anything..
(laugh)
Just to use this as a story.
How do we inspire other people to do the same things.
The title of my first album is "Good Spell".

Goodspell, goodspell, If there is a good spell, 
then there is a bad spell.

Goodspell is a positive mantra. 
And I'm sure through music,

.. We can create a positive mantra. 
to invite people to do good.
One of the things i focused on there, is prioritizing God in life.

Where we have to be bold to place God as number one in life. 
And ofcourse,

I am not talking about a religion.
But, I'm talking about cross religion.
We have to bring that in our daily lives.
That's why I think, I do it.
(Audience applause)
Thank you.

Because sometimes we forget. 
Maybe we think we're too smart.
Or maybe we think we have enough knowledge.
Sometimes we forget that there is one,

One entity bigger than ourselves. 
And that God created us all.
And we have to be grateful, all the time.
And that is what i tried to communicate in my first album.

In the second album that I'm currently working on
"Generasi Sinergi".
Why is the title "Generasi Sinergi" ?

Because, like what I see now.
With all the speakers here.
We all come from different backgrounds.

There's Ade Rai,
with a health and fitness background

There's Irwan Ahmett, with his concept
of play that is very exciting.
And then there will be Dr. Nurul.

We try to show something new, 
And at the end, it can be synergized.
From all these different fields.

Entertainment, Technology, Design.
We can unite them.

And we can create great synergy. 
A better synchronization of energy.
And I pray that that will be
.. a new progress and change for Indonesia. that..
(Audience applause)
A bit more.. Just a bit more, before I play again.

Settle down, Settle down
I am holding a bass not for nothing.
(laugh)

And what i try to communicate 
through the second album is..

to lift and burn the love of the youth 
towards our nation, Indonesia.
Because there are a lot of skepticism with young people now.

"argh.. Indonesia won't move forward
It's just gonna be the same old, same old".

And most of them can only complain. 
While, I'd like to say to them,

That it's time for us to move!
and not just protest.
The time is not only just to be critical,
but to move and create the change.

Because the thing about change,is that
it always begin from ourselves.
(Audience applause)
I still have 6 minutes over there.
5.58, 5.57 and it keeps on going..
(laugh)
I'm gonna try to make something, i hope..
We'll just see, I guess.
I don't even know what I will play.
(playing - Tanah Air Beta)
(Audience cheer and applaud)
(Audience cheer and applaud)
Thank you once again, good bless you all.

comments.author: El3ctricOr

comments.text:
+Niall Lyn-McKee That's not my point.
My point is that whether you are better or not, doesn't matter, and the 
fact that he felt he had to point it out, just leads me to believe that 
it's a case of playing devil's advocate, like every other fucking internet 
asshole in the existence ever, and back when I replied to this guy I'm 
gonna go out on a limb and say I most likely had a bad day, on top of 
seeing nothing but negativity in a comment section mixed in with a whole 
lot of arrogance just tipped the scales for me I suppose. 

Now, let's just leave at that, that we disagree with one another, I'm not 
feeling this topic anymore, and if I have to justify my arguments for every 
single bypasser that comments on ancient threads, I'm gonna be old before 
I'll ever be done.
Good day to you.
comments.author: Alex Wayne

comments.text:
+Alex Wayne Sure, but thats the case with everything, especially on the 
internet. We can know if said person speaks the truth because many other 
people in the world can confirm it by personal experience. Its not 
far-fetched that a better bassist watches TED. And for certain criticisms, 
one only has to be a moderately-trained musician with relative pitch to 
notice them. Your uncertainty stems from your lack of knowledge about the 
subject, not OP's lack of visible credentials. Some people call that 
elitist, but its the case with any learned subject. I guess we will have to 
agree to disagree, yes.
comments.author: Niall Lyn-McKee

comments.text:
+Niall Lyn-McKee I guess we're just gonna have to agree to disagree.
Using your own "experience" to support an argument doesn't make it valid, 
because there's a very high chance that we'll never know if said person 
speaks the truth or if they're just trying to sound superior.
comments.author: Alex Wayne

comments.text: +Alex Wayne Because ElectricOr's criticism's are valid
comments.author: Niall Lyn-McKee

comments.text: +Niall Lyn-McKee Why are you saying this to me? I'm supporting the guy.
comments.author: Alex Wayne

comments.text:
+Alex Wayne Actually, OP's experience level does make a difference... it 
means he knows shit about the subject. If you need video proof then maybe 
you're just skeptical to the point of being a prick. I think the player is 
good, but Im not going to sit here and pretend I know he's perfect. As a 
percussionist for 15 years I do hear some tempo and tuning issues. He's 
good but a metronome could do him some good too. Check out Victor Wooten's 
bass solos.
comments.author: Niall Lyn-McKee

when I watched this video I was getting a vibe from him that he is the best

comments.text:

comments.author: ic0n

comments.text:
+Gede Andiyastika
Good points. Thanks for the reply
comments.author: TheNeapolitanChord

comments.text:
As much as I want to disagree with you, I'll have to accept the fact that 
he does copy a good number of famous bass players such as Victor Wooten and 
he's not as good as those world class bass players. However, I'm afraid 
you're not seeing the point. The reason why he's becoming famous is, in my 
opinion, because of the music industry currently existing in Indonesia and 
the people's outlook on music in Indonesia. Indonesia's music industry is 
crap, for the most part. It's focused entirely on business only. Barry 
proved that he could change that with his limited knowledge of bass 
playing. Barry also uses music styles that are unfamiliar to the Indonesian 
population's ears as a way of expressing himself. Barry also has a desire 
to let the talented Indonesian musicians shine in front of the people and 
let them get the props that they deserve.

As an Indonesian bass player, I find that he's leading a revolution in the 
Indonesian music industry and the common stereotypes given to the 
Indonesian people, and that's what makes him worthy of a TED talk.
comments.author: Gede Andiyastika

comments.text:
+TheNeapolitanChord
 ur just jealous hahahaaaa
comments.author: vinza pramana putra

comments.text:
+Yosua Pane
I actually have been playing bass for about 7 years very adamantly and do 
not consider myself worthy of a TED talk. I do, however consider myself at 
least as good as this guy. I would respect him if I met him somewhere. I 
will not respect giving him the spotlight when he clearly doesn't deserve 
it. I'm not jealous. I acknowledge I also don't deserve it, nor do I even 
think I'm any better. About the same technical skill with a different style.

You, on the other hand, seem to know nothing about music if you think his 
playing is worthy of recognition in his adolescent phase of musical 
maturity.
comments.author: TheNeapolitanChord

comments.text:
+Oswaldo Rios It seems often to come from radio jocks, they are imbeciles. 
They'll spend all day playing tracks that are purely built off nothing but 
bass playing, they'll organise festivals were people dance all day and 
night to bass playing with drums, then they make dumb comments about how 
bass is a joke, worthless and contributes nothing to the music they listen 
to and they'll do this to just about every single studio guest. Pure 
morons. For them it must all be about who has a face with makeup on it.

comments.author: detinfrabric

comments.text:
+XenoFect
And this is what's wrong with the music industry today. Closed minded 
people. This instrument is only for this and this one can only play in this 
part. Bull, the bass guitar for example can also be a lead instrument, it 
can be rhythm, it can be whatever the hell it wants. It doesn't have to 
only "hold the bottom end". Have you ever heard of the band "Tool"? So no 
it doesn't only hold the bottom end.  Being a bassist myself i know this 
for a fact. In plenty of songs i play the bass does more then keep a beat 
or hold a low end. But when you add people like +godofrock yeah and +
MrKimchiNinja you come out with the kind of music you hear today. The same 
old crap. No evolution.
 Rant off.
comments.author: Dylan Stassen (Bassman415)

comments.text:
With such closed minded thinking like that, we might never have had bands 
like Rush, Kiss, Primus, etc. Music is suppose to be an open method of 
expression, not conforming to someone's ideals of what they like. It's too 
create and share an experience. Create something positive.
comments.author: XenoFect

comments.text:

comments.text:
He just turned the bass into a lead instrument. Come on its awesome. And I

comments.author: Richard Morse

comments.text:
+MrKimchiNinja Drums only need to supply the beat. No need to get tricky. 
See what I did there? That's a painfully ignorant view of what musicianship 
is about. 

As to the first comment, the specific tuning, tone and techniques used in 
the bass arrangement he provided are distinctive to this instrument and 
would require some considerable tweaking to duplicate on a guitar...but, 
then again, why would you want to?
comments.author: Andarovin

comments.text:
The "purpose of bass guitar" is the same as any other instrument. It makes 
pleasant or otherwise moving sounds.  How those sounds are used is 
completely up to the artist or composer, which was the whole point of the 
TED talk.
